    Download Hi-Res ImageDownload to MS-PowerPointCite This:J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 11, 5797-5815

    In Vitro and in Vivo Evaluation of Membrane-Active Flavone Amphiphiles: Semisynthetic Kaempferol-Derived Antimicrobials against Drug-Resistant Gram-Positive Bacteria

    • Shuimu Lin
      Shuimu Lin
      Key Laboratory of Molecular Target & Clinical Pharmacology and the State Key Laboratory of Respiratory Disease, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences & the Fifth Affiliated Hospital, Guangzhou Medical University, Guangzhou 511436, P. R. China

    SUBJECTS:
    • Antimicrobial agents,
    • Reaction products,
    • Bacteria,
    • Membranes,
    • Antibacterial activity
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Because of the rapid increase in bacterial resistance, there is an urgent need for developing new antimicrobial agents to combat multidrug-resistant pathogens. In this study, we designed and synthesized a series of kaempferol derivatives as antimicrobial agents biomimicking the structural properties and biological functions of host defense peptides. After fine-tuning of hydrophobic and cationic hydrophilic moieties linked to the flavone scaffold of kaempferol, we obtained a lead compound (52) that displayed high membrane selectivity (>128), poor hemolytic activity, low cytotoxicity to mammalian cells, and excellent activity against Gram-positive bacteria (minimum inhibitory concentrations = 1.56 μg/mL), including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Compound 52 can kill bacteria quickly by destroying the bacterial membranes and avoid developing bacterial resistance. Moreover, compound 52 exhibited potent in vivo antibacterial activity against S. aureus in a murine corneal infection model. These results indicated that compound 52 had the therapeutic potential as a novel membrane-active antimicrobial to combat Gram-positive bacterial infections.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Recently, because of the abuse of antimicrobial agents and the lack of new antimicrobial agents, bacterial resistance has risen dramatically, which is seriously endangering public health.(1−3) The pharmaceutical company’s investment in research and development of antimicrobial agents has dropped significantly because antimicrobial agents have a short lifespan and are more prone to developing drug resistance, resulting in reduced profits.(4) Current treatment options for drug-resistant bacterial infections are inadequate, often accompanied by high medical costs, high morbidity, and high mortality.(5−8) Considering this serious situation, the World Health Organization recently issued a global priority pathogen list of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and listed bacterial resistance as one of the top 10 health threats in the world.(9) If we do not pay enough attention to the emergence of superbugs, the number of deaths caused by drug-resistant pathogen infections will increase dramatically from about 700,000 patients each year to 10 million patients each year by 2050.(10) Therefore, it is very urgent to develop novel antimicrobial agents with new antibacterial mechanisms for treating drug-resistant bacterial infections.(11)
    Host defense peptides (HDPs), also known as antimicrobial peptides, are a key component of the innate immune system.(12−14) They are generally composed of 10–50 amino acid residues to form a positively charged amphiphilic configuration, showing a great advantage in avoiding bacterial resistance.(12,15) Unlike conventional antimicrobial agents with specific targets, most HDPs can kill bacteria quickly by destroying the bacterial cell membranes and have nonspecific targets, leading to an effective reduction in the probability of drug resistance.(13) However, the clinical application of HDPs is also constrained by several defects such as high toxicity, low in vivo stability, and high manufacturing costs.(16,17) In recent years, in order to solve the inherent defects of HDPs, researchers have developed a series of novel membrane-active small-molecule-based HDP mimics by simulating HDPs in chemical structure and biological functions.(18−22) So far, several small-molecule-based HDP mimics have successfully entered clinical trials, such as brilacidin(23,24) and LTX109.(25)
    Flavone derivatives are widely found in vegetables and fruits, which are generally beneficial to human health and have no side effects.(26−28) Flavone derivatives have been reported to contain a variety of remarkable pharmacological activities such as antibacterial,(29) antioxidant,(30,31) antiviral,(32) anticancer activities,(33) and so forth. In our previous work, we used natural icaritin as the starting material to develop membrane-targeting flavone-based antimicrobial agents by biomimicking the chemical structure and biological functions of HDPs.(34) One of the optimized compounds showed potent in vitro and in vivo antimicrobial activity against Gram-positive bacteria, which can kill bacteria rapidly by destroying the integrity of the bacterial membranes and avert the development of drug resistance in laboratory assays.(34) Nevertheless, this strategy for developing flavone-based antimicrobials has some obvious shortcomings, such as the high cost of the starting material icaritin and limited modification sites in chemical synthesis.
    Kaempferol (3,5,7,4′-tetrahydroxyflavone) is abundantly found in vegetables, fruits, teas, and Chinese herbal medicine.(35,36) It has been reported that kaempferol existed in 80% of plant-based foods and displays a variety of biological activities including anti-inflammatory,(37) antioxidant,(38) anticancer,(39) anticoagulant activities,(40) and so forth. However, kaempferol is poorly water-soluble, affecting the preparation of intravenous injection and the in vivo absorption.(37,41,42) Moreover, kaempferol contains four phenolic hydroxyl groups, which can be covalently bonded to endogenous molecules such as glucuronic acid, glycine, and sulfuric acid, leading to strong first-pass metabolism and poor pharmacokinetic properties.(37,42,43) This work will improve the water solubility and pharmacokinetic properties of kaempferol derivatives through structural modification to solve the defects of kaempferol in clinical applications.
    Herein, we designed and synthesized a new class of membrane-active flavone amphiphiles with potent antibacterial activity using kaempferol as a starting material and biomimicking the chemical structure and mode of action of HDPs (Figure 1). It is well known that two “last-resort” marketed antibiotics, including daptomycin and polymyxin, can associate and interact with bacterial membranes.(44−47) This design strategy will use cheap kaempferol as a starting material, which can significantly reduce the cost of preparation and provide more alternative modification options as compared to icaritin, resulting in the rapid generation of a new library of flavone amphiphiles as antimicrobial agents (Figure 1). Kaempferol provides the important flavone scaffold that is small and conformationally rigid hydrophobic core. We hypothesized that the incorporated cationic moieties that provide positive charges and hydrophilicity can promote the interaction between flavone compounds and negatively charged bacterial cell membranes via electrostatic interaction, and then the incorporation of lipid chains together with the flavone core can facilitate the insertion of flavone compounds into bacterial phospholipid bilayer membranes. Because the mammalian cell membranes are zwitterionic,(48,49) the cationic flavone amphiphiles could greatly enhance the selectivity between bacterial and mammalian cell membranes. Fine-tuning of the hydrophobic and cationic hydrophilic moieties of kaempferol derivatives was performed to obtain membrane-active antimicrobial agents with potent antibacterial activity, high membrane selectivity, and low toxicity. Finally, time-kill kinetics, resistance development, antibacterial mechanism, and in vivo antibacterial efficacy in a murine corneal infection model for selected compounds were further investigated. These findings suggest that this design strategy for kaempferol-based HDP mimics can help to pave a way for the development of novel antimicrobial agents.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Design and Synthesis of Kaempferol-Based Antibacterial Analogues

    The synthetic routes used to yield various amphiphilic kaempferol analogues are illustrated in Schemes 1−5. The starting material kaempferol was alkylated with about 2 equiv of corresponding 1-iodoalkane or 3,3-dimethylallyl bromide together with K2CO3 to afford compounds 1–5. The phenolic hydroxyl group at the C3, C7, and C4′ positions was more active than that at the C5 position because there was stable intramolecular hydrogen bond formation between the C5 phenolic hydroxyl group and C4 carbonyl group.(50,51) The alkylations of compounds 1–5 with 1,3-dibromopropane in the presence of K2CO3 provided compounds 6–10. Compounds 6–10 were then treated with diethylamine to yield compounds 11–15. Compound 5 was then alkylated with the corresponding α,ω-dibromoalkanes to afford compounds 16–21, followed by treating with diethylamine to yield compounds 22–27. The treatment of compound 10 with corresponding amines resulted in compounds 28–37. To synthesize compounds 38–40, compounds 28, 15, and 30 were coupled with iodomethane. Kaempferol was alkylated with 2 or 4 equiv of ethyl bromoacetate in the presence of K2CO3 to provide compounds 41–42. Compounds 41–42 were then hydrolyzed by LiOH to produce acids 43–44. The respective acids 43–44 were then reacted with H-Arg-OMe·2HCl, H-His-OMe·2HCl, N,N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine, or N,N-diethyl-1,3-propanediamine in the presence of 2-(3H-[1,2,3]triazolo[4,5-b]pyridin-3-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethylisouronium hexafluorophosphate (HATU) and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) to yield compounds 45–48 and 52–54. The treatment of compound 45 with LiOH produced compound 49, which was then coupled with H-Arg-OMe·2HCl or N,N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine using HATU and DIPEA to afford compounds 50–51. All synthesized compounds were characterized by NMR and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS).

    In Vitro Antibacterial and Hemolytic Activity

    The in vitro antibacterial activities of the kaempferol derivatives were assessed against four Gram-positive pathogens, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), by determining their minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs). The hemolytic activities (HC50) toward rabbit erythrocytes were measured to evaluate the membrane selectivity (HC50/MICs) of these synthesized compounds.
    Compounds 11–15 containing the same cationic moiety were prepared to evaluate the effect of different lipid chains on the biological activity of the kaempferol derivatives (Table 1). Both compounds 11 and 12, in which the lipid chains consisted of two n-propyl and two n-pentyl groups, respectively, displayed good antimicrobial activities (MICs = 6.25–12.5 μg/mL) and weak hemolytic activities (HC50 = 58.5 ± 0.6 μg/mL for compound 11 and HC50 = 153.4 ± 3.3 μg/mL for compound 12). Increasing the lipid chain lengths yielded two more hydrophobic compounds 13–14. Both compounds 13–14 displayed poor antibacterial and hemolytic activities, with MICs >50 μg/mL and HC50 values >200 μg/mL. Significantly, compound 15 bearing two isoprenyl groups exhibited the most potent antibacterial activities (MICs = 3.13 μg/mL) among the five compounds. This result is consistent with previous studies where the isoprenyl groups would greatly promote the insertion of cationic amphiphilic compounds into the hydrophobic regions of the Gram-positive bacterial membranes and accelerate their bactericidal action.(21,51) Therefore, the isoprenyl groups were selected as the key hydrophobic lipid groups in this study.
    Table 1. In Vitro Antibacterial and Hemolytic Activities of Kaempferol Derivatives 1–40
     MIC, μg/mL (μM) 
    compdS. aureus ATCC 29213MRSA N315MRSA NCTC10442HC50, μg/mL (μM)

    3512.5 (24.0)3.125 (6.0)6.25 (12.0)26.0 ± 0.7 (49.8 ± 1.3)
    3625 (45.5)6.25 (11.4)12.5 (22.7)38.3 ± 1.8 (69.7 ± 3.3)
    37>50 (>84.5)12.5 (21.1)>50 (>84.5)>200 (>338.0)
    383.125 (4.8)1.56 (2.4)3.125 (4.8)50.2 ± 0.7 (77.3 ± 1.1)
    393.125 (4.6)1.56 (2.3)3.125 (4.6)59.7 ± 1.6 (88.2 ± 2.4)
    4012.5 (17.1)12.5 (17.1)25 (34.1)34.4 ± 2.1 (46.9 ± 2.9)
    vancomycin0.78 (0.54)1.56 (1.08)1.56 (1.08)ND
    To investigate the effect of spacer lengths on the biological activity of the kaempferol derivatives, diethylamine-coupled compounds 15 and 22–27 were prepared (Table 1). Compounds 15 and 23 (n = 3 and 4, respectively) displayed significant potency against all tested bacterial strains (MICs = 3.13 μg/mL). Their antibacterial activity was gradually reduced as the spacer lengths of kaempferol derivatives increased, with a spacer length of n > 4. The MIC values for both compounds 24 (n = 5) and 25 (n = 6) are in the range of 6.25–12.5 μg/mL. Compound 26 (n = 8) showed greatly diminished antimicrobial activities, with MICs of 12.5–50 μg/mL. No antibacterial activity (MICs >50 μg/mL) and hemolytic activity (HC50 > 200 μg/mL) were observed for compound 27 with the longest spacer length of n = 10. Surprisingly, compound 22 with a spacer length of n = 2 displayed very poor antibacterial activity (MICs = 50 μg/mL) and very poor hemolytic activity (HC50 > 200 μg/mL). However, the reason as to why a too short spacer length (n = 2) resulted in poor antimicrobial and hemolytic activities is still unclear. Compounds 15 and 23–26 with spacer lengths of n = 3–8 showed moderately hemolytic activities because the membrane selectivity (HC50/MIC) of compound 15 (n = 3) is approximately twice as high as that of compound 23 (n = 4). Thus, a spacer length of n = 3 was used as the best spacer length in the further structural optimization study.
    Next, compounds 15 and 28–40 were synthesized to explore the effects of different kinds of amine group substitutions on the bioactivity of kaempferol derivatives (Table 1). These compounds contained varied cationic amine groups while keeping the same lipid chains of two isoprenyl groups and the same spacer lengths of n = 3. Tertiary amine-substituted flavone compounds 15 (N,N-diethylamine-coupled) and 28 (N,N-dimethylamine-coupled) displayed potent antibacterial activity against all tested strains, with MICs of 3.125 and 6.25 μg/mL, respectively. Replacements using N,N-dipropylamine (29) and N,N-dibutylamine (30) instead of N,N-diethylamine (15) resulted in significant loss in antibacterial and hemolytic activities, with MICs >50 μg/mL and HC50 >200 μg/mL. When incorporating pyrrolidine (31) and 1-methylpiperazine (32), a two-fold reduction in antibacterial activity was observed, with MICs of 6.25–12.5 μg/mL. Owing to the lower pKa values of the introduced amine groups, thiomorpholine-coupled compound 33 (pKa of free thiomorpholine = 9.0)(52) and morpholine-coupled compound 34 (pKa of free morpholine = 8.36)(53) displayed very poor antibacterial activities (MICs > 50 μg/mL) and very poor hemolytic activities (HC50 > 200 μg/mL). These results suggested that the amine substituents with long carbon chains or lower pKa values were deleterious to the antimicrobial and hemolytic activities.
    As shown in Tables 1 and 2, secondary amine-substituted flavone compounds 35 (n-propylamine-coupled) and 36 (n-pentylamine-coupled) showed moderately antibacterial activities (MICs = 3.13–25 μg/mL) and moderately hemolytic activities. A more hydrophobic compound, 37 (n-octylamine-coupled), displayed dramatically reduced activity (MICs > 50 μg/mL against S. aureus ATCC29213 and MRSA NCTC10442; MICs = 12.5 μg/mL against MRSA N315) and poor hemolytic activities (HC50 > 200 μg/mL). Tertiary amines 28, 15, and 30 were treated with iodomethane to yield quaternary ammonium salts 38–40. Both compounds 38–39 still retained similarly excellent antibacterial activities against Gram-positive bacteria as their precursor compounds 28 and 15. In contrast, compound 40 showed an obvious enhancement in both antibacterial and hemolytic activities as compared with its precursor compound 30, with MICs of 12.5–25 μg/mL and HC50 of 34.4 ± 2.1 μg/mL. These results suggested that suitable tertiary amine or quaternary ammonium salt substituents can lead to potent anti-Gram-positive bacterial activities for cationic flavone compounds.
    Table 2. In Vitro Antibacterial and Hemolytic Activities of Kaempferol Derivatives 45–54
     MIC, μg/mL (μM) 
    compdS. aureus ATCC 29213MRSA N315MRSA NCTC10442HC50, μg/mL (μM)
    453.125 (4.8)1.56 (2.4)3.125 (4.8)69.8 ± 1.5 (107.3 ± 2.3)
    46>50 (>79.2)>50 (>79.2)>50 (>79.2)>200 (>316.6)
    476.25 (11.1)6.25 (11.1)12.5 (22.1)162.1 ± 1.6 (287.1 ± 2.8)
    486.25 (10.5)6.25 (10.5)12.5 (21.1)47.6 ± 0.7 (80.3 ± 1.2)
    503.125 (3.9)3.125 (3.9)3.125 (3.9)66.6 ± 1.5 (82.5 ± 1.9)
    516.25 (8.7)6.25 (8.7)6.25 (8.7)94.3 ± 1.0 (130.8 ± 1.4)
    521.56 (1.8)1.56 (1.8)1.56 (1.8)>200 (>227.5)
    5325 (35.4)50 (70.7)50 (70.7)>200 (>282.9)
    54>50 (>65.5)>50 (>65.5)>50 (>65.5)>200 (>262.1)
    vancomycin0.78 (0.54)1.56 (1.08)1.56 (1.08)ND
    Inspired by the enhanced antimicrobial activity and membrane selectivity caused by the incorporation of aliphatic amines, we then prepared compounds 45–46 and 50–52 to investigate the effect of basic amino acid (e.g., arginine) substituents on the biological activity (Table 2). Basic amino acids are good candidates as cationic groups appending to the flavone scaffold because they can introduce positive charges and increase molecular hydrophilicity and biocompatibility for the flavone compounds. Compound 45, with one arginine substitution at the C3 position of the flavone scaffold, displayed potent antibacterial activity (MICs = 1.56–3.13 μg/mL) and weak hemolytic activity (HC50 = 69.8 ± 1.5 μg/mL). Coupling one more arginine at the same position (compound 50) resulted in similar activities, with MICs of 3.13 μg/mL and HC50 of 66.6 ± 1.5 μg/mL. Compound 51 containing one arginine residue that was capped with 1,3-propanediamine instead of −OMe (45) displayed a two-fold reduction in antimicrobial activity (MICs = 6.25 μg/mL). The incorporation of low pKa amino acid (compound 46, histidine, pKa of the side chain of 6.10)(34) led to a significant loss in antibacterial and hemolytic activities.
    Finally, we investigated the effect of biological activity of 3,5-disubstituted flavone derivatives (52–54) with two cationic moieties and 3-monosubstituted flavone derivatives (45, 47–48, and 50) with one or two cationic moieties. Compounds 47–48 that included dimethylamine or diethylamine substitution at the C3 position of the flavone scaffold displayed good antibacterial activity (MICs = 6.25 μg/mL) and weak hemolytic activity. Surprisingly, poor antibacterial and hemolytic activities were observed for compounds 53–54 that contained dimethylamine or diethylamine substitution at the C3 and C5 positions of the flavone scaffold. We also planned to use α,ω-dibromoalkanes or α,ω-diiodoalkanes to prepare 3,5-dihalogenated flavone intermediates that were then reacted with diethylamine to yield bisalkane amine-substituted compounds. However, we failed to obtain 3,5-dihalogenated flavone intermediates. 3,5-Disubstituted flavone compound 52 containing an arginine group exhibited better antibacterial activity against all the strains tested (MICs = 1.56 μg/mL) than that of 3-monosubstituted flavone compounds 45 and 50 containing an arginine group. It should be noted that compound 52 showed very poor hemolytic activity, with HC50 >200 μg/mL. Even at the highest tested concentration of 200 μg/mL, compound 52 caused only 32.8 ± 1.0% hemolysis of red blood cells (RBCs). Therefore, compound 52 has very high membrane selectivity, with a membrane selectivity index of >128. The incorporation of arginine residue at the C5 position can further increase the hydrophilicity of the flavone compound and make the positive charges be more uniformly dispersed, resulting in a significant decrease in hemolytic activity. We have also screened the activity against Gram-negative bacteria for compounds 45 and 52 (Table S1). Poor anti-Gram-negative bacterial activity was observed for compound 45. Compound 52 displayed moderate activity (MICs = 12.5–25 μg/mL) against the tested Gram-negative strains, including one Escherichia coli and three Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains. The reason may be that the lipopolysaccharide layer outside the Gram-negative bacterial inner membranes hinders the entry of kaempferol compounds.
    From the preliminary structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies, we found that the membrane-targeting properties of flavone compounds are determined by the following distinct structural parameters: lipid chains, spacer lengths, cationic moieties, and the balance of hydrophobic and cationic moieties. The lipid chains are important to provide a driving force to facilitate the insertion of flavone compounds into bacterial phospholipid bilayer membranes. Among these different lipid chains, the isoprenyl groups resulted in the best antibacterial activities. This result is consistent with previous studies where the isoprenyl groups would greatly promote the insertion between cationic amphiphilic compounds and bacterial membranes.(21,51) The SAR study indicated that spacer lengths of 4–6 were beneficial to improve the antibacterial activity. The amphiphilic flavone compounds with too short (n = 2) or too long spacer lengths (n ≥ 8) would result in a great reduction or even loss in antibacterial activity. The cationic moieties of flavone compounds played a key role in the interaction with the negatively charged bacterial membranes. The incorporation of high pKa amine groups could enhance the antimicrobial activity of amphiphilic flavone compounds. By contrast, poor antibacterial activity was observed for the incorporation of low pKa amine groups (i.e., thiomorpholine and morpholine). Additionally, the introduced amine groups bearing long hydrophobic side chains (total carbon chains ≥ 6) would result in the loss of antibacterial activity (MIC > 50 μg/mL) for flavone compounds. Compared with flavone compounds substituted by aliphatic amines, arginine-substituted compounds not only maintain excellent antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria but also reduce the hemolytic activity, resulting in the higher membrane selectivity.

    Time-Kill Kinetics

    The bactericidal rate of flavone derivatives was investigated by the time-kill kinetic assay. As shown in Figure 2, compounds 45 and 52 reduced 3.19 and 3.21 log bacteria (killing ≥99.9% of S. aureus ATCC29213) within 1 h at 4× MIC and reduced 3.78 and 3.22 log bacteria within 0.5 h at 8× MIC, as well as no regrowth of bacteria was observed within 24 h. In contrast, traditional vancomycin just reached 1.18 log reduction of bacteria after 8 h at 4× MIC concentration. These results indicated that these two compounds can rapidly kill Gram-positive bacteria, which would shorten the treatment time of bacterial infection and reduce the probability of bacterial resistance development.

    Antibacterial Mechanism Studies

    The antibacterial mechanism of the selected kaempferol derivatives was first studied using SYTOX Green dye. SYTOX Green is a high-affinity nucleic acid stain that can easily penetrate damaged bacterial cell membranes and bind to nucleic acids in cells, resulting in enhanced fluorescence intensity.(54−56)Figure 3 shows the effect of compounds 45 and 52 at four different concentrations (1×, 2×, 4×, and 8× MIC) against S. aureus ATCC29213 incubated with SYTOX Green. Both potent compounds 45 and 52 at the concentrations of 1×, 2×, 4×, and 8× MIC induced an obvious increase in fluorescence intensity, indicating a very strong interaction between compounds 45 and 52 and the bacterial cell membranes, leading to the strong cytoplasmic membrane permeabilization. Meanwhile, we carried out the fluorescence experiments without the addition of SYTOX Green as an additional control, showing very weak fluorescence signals (Figure S1). This result clearly proved that the measured fluorescence in Figure 3 did not come from the antimicrobial compounds themselves. These data demonstrated that compounds 45 and 52 can cause the deaths of Gram-positive bacteria by destroying the bacterial cell membranes, resulting in the leakage of internal contents of bacterial cells and the deaths of bacteria.
    Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is applied to observe the morphological changes of bacteria (S. aureus ATCC29213) treated by compound 45 or 52 (8× MIC). As shown in Figure 4, without the treatment of flavone compounds, bacterial cells showed a normal smooth surface. In contrast, bacterial cells treated by 45 or 52 displayed very obvious cell surface disruption. The loss of structural integrity in bacterial cells exposed to either compound 45 or compound 52 was clearly observed with an indication of bacterial cell deaths via lysis.
    Finally, the bacterial membrane integrity was determined by using the LIVE/DEAD bacterial viability assay. Propidium iodide (PI) and SYTO 9 are commonly used to measure the bacterial membrane integrity.(57,58) PI cannot penetrate the intact cell membranes but can penetrate the damaged cell membranes and stains the dead bacterial cells red.(57,58) SYTO 9 can penetrate both intact and damaged membranes and stains the cells green.(57,58) As shown in Figure 5, after compounds 45 and 52 were incubated with S. aureus ATCC29213 for 2 h, only obvious red fluorescence was observed, suggesting that compounds 45 and 52 can cause the deaths of bacteria by destroying the bacterial cell membrane integrity. By contrast, only obvious green fluorescence was observed for the phosphate-buffered saline (PBS)-treated group because PBS is unable to destroy bacterial cell membranes and cause the bacterial cell deaths. These results indicated that compounds 45 and 52 can effectively kill Gram-positive bacteria by destroying their cell membranes.

    Resistance Development Study

    The emergence of bacterial resistance to traditional antimicrobials seriously hinders the effective treatment of infectious diseases.(59,60) Drug resistance development has become a crucial factor in designing and evaluating new antimicrobials.(61,62) To evaluate the ability of compounds 45 and 52 to avoid acute antibacterial resistance, we performed a multipassage resistance selection assay by consecutively passaging S. aureus ATCC29213 in the presence of sublethal concentrations of compounds 45 and 52 and norfloxacin for 19 cycles over a period of 19 consecutive days. As shown in Figure 6, no greater than a 4-fold increase in the MIC values was observed for both compounds 45 and 52 after 19 passages. In contrast, norfloxacin induced bacterial resistance rapidly, and the MIC value was increased by 128-fold after 15 passages. The rapid bactericidal activity and membrane-targeting action are very beneficial for compounds 45 and 52 to overcome the emergence of drug resistance. The resistance of membrane-targeting antimicrobial agents typically requires large-scale changes in the membrane composition of bacteria, but it is very difficult for the bacteria to maintain viability when remodeling cell membranes.(63−65) These results demonstrated that compounds 45 and 52 can avoid the development of bacterial resistance.

    In Vitro Cytotoxicity Evaluation

    Based on the in vitro antibacterial and hemolytic activity, two compounds (45 and 52) were selected for the cytotoxicity evaluation toward mammalian cells (MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells or mouse corneal epithelial cells) using the CCK-8 method. As shown in Figure 7, both compounds showed very low cytotoxicity with a CC50 value of >50 μg/mL. Even at the highest tested concentration (16× MIC for compound 45 and 32× MIC for compound 52), compounds 45 and 52 still retained cell survival rates of 67.3 ± 3.7 and 75.0 ± 4.7% toward MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells as well as 62.1 ± 1.7 and 70.1 ± 2.1% toward mouse corneal epithelial cells, indicating that both compounds had high safety toward mammalian cells.

    In Vivo Antibacterial Efficacy

    Compound 52 exhibited the most excellent in vitro antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria and the highest membrane selectivity among all synthetic kaempferol derivatives. This important finding prompted us to evaluate its in vivo antibacterial efficacy in a murine corneal infection model. Antimicrobial agents, which are used by topical administration for the treatment of ocular infections, can avoid the side effects of systemic administration and greatly increase the drug concentration in the infected area.(66) In this study, a murine immunosuppression model was prepared by treating cyclophosphamide, and then the murine corneas were infected with S. aureus ATCC29213. One day after bacterial infection, mice were randomly divided into three groups (five mice per group), and each group of mice was topically treated with either 0.5% compound 52, 5% vancomycin (positive control), or 5% glucose (negative control). The mice were treated four times a day for 3 days. Vancomycin solution (5%) is commonly applied in the clinical treatment of bacterial keratitis.(67) Because vancomycin has poor corneal permeability, the concentration required in the treatment of corneal infections is high.(68) As shown in Figure 8, compound 52 and vancomycin achieved 3.28 log (p < 0.05) and 3.99 log (p < 0.05) reduction of S. aureus count in the infected cornea, respectively. Compound 52 exhibited potent in vivo antibacterial activity comparable to that of vancomycin, although its concentration was 10 times lower than that of vancomycin. These results indicate that compound 52 is very promising in the treatment of murine corneal infection caused by S. aureus.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In summary, we have designed and synthesized a novel series of flavone-based antimicrobial agents that were derived from natural kaempferol by biomimicking the chemical structure and biological functions of HDPs. The design strategy can enhance water solubility, drug-like properties, and antibacterial activity of kaempferol-derived compounds, enabling them to overcome multidrug-resistant bacteria. After a series of structural optimization and SAR studies, compound 52 was identified as the most promising antibacterial agent with low cytotoxicity to mammalian cells (CC50 > 50 μg/mL), low hemolytic activity (HC50 > 200 μg/mL), high membrane selectivity (>128), and excellent activity against Gram-positive bacteria (MICs = 1.56 μg/mL), including MRSA. Compound 52 showed rapid bactericidal properties, reaching > 3 log reduction for S. aureus ATCC29213 within 0.5 h at 8× MIC and within 1 h at 4× MIC. The mode of action studies revealed that there was a strong interaction between compound 52 and the bacterial cell membranes; compound 52 can directly destroy the bacterial cell membranes in a concentration-dependent manner, resulting in the deaths of bacterial cells. Remarkably, 52 showed an excellent antibacterial efficacy in a murine corneal infection model induced by S. aureus ATCC29213. In general, we have developed a new class of kaempferol derivatives as membrane-active antimicrobial agents, providing a promising approach for combating drug-resistant pathogen infections.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Chemistry

    All commercial chemicals and solvents were used without further purification. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL 400 MHz spectrometer operating at 400 and 100 MHz, respectively. Chemical shifts (δ) are given in parts per million (ppm), and coupling constants (J) are expressed in hertz (Hz). Preparative high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed on an Agilent 1260 Infinity system (YMC-Pack, C18 column, 20 × 150 mm, 5 μm, 120 Å) using a proper gradient (20–95%) of methanol and distilled water containing 0.1% HCOOH as the mobile phase. All final compounds possessed a purity of ≥95%. The purity of each final compound was determined by analytical HPLC on a Water 2695 unit with a Water SunFire C18 column (5 μm, 4.6 × 100 mm). HRMS spectra were recorded on a Thermo DFS mass spectrometer.

    3,5-Dihydroxy-7-propoxy-2-(4-propoxyphenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (1)

    To a solution of kaempferol (100 mg, 0.349 mmol) in dimethylformamide (DMF) (15 mL), potassium carbonate (120 mg, 0.873 mmol) was added. After stirring for 0.5 h at RT, 1-iodopropane (70.4 μL, 0.722 mmol) was added to the solution. Then, the mixture was stirred at RT for 10 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 3:1, v/v) to give compound 1 as a yellow solid (56.5 mg, 45%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.62 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 6.98 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 6.32 (m, 2H), 3.98 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.91 (t, J = 6.7 Hz, 2H), 1.89–1.79 (m, 2H), 1.76–1.66 (m, 2H), 1.04 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H), 0.91 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.1, 165.2, 161.8, 157.0, 156.9 (2× C), 137.9, 130.7 (2× CH), 122.5, 115.8 (2× CH), 105.9, 98.5, 92.8, 74.9, 70.3, 23.3, 22.4, 10.5, 10.4. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C21H23O6 [M + H]+, 371.1495; found, 371.1484.

    3,5-Dihydroxy-7-(pentyloxy)-2-(4-(pentyloxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (2)

    Compound 2 was synthesized from kaempferol (100 mg, 0.349 mmol), potassium carbonate (240 mg, 1.75 mmol), and 1-iodopentane (95.6 μL, 0.73 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 1. The product was obtained as a yellow solid (68.1 mg, 45%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.63 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 6.99 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 6.43 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 6.34 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 4.01 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.94 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H), 1.96–1.64 (m, 4H), 1.61–1.08 (m, 8H), 0.93 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H), 0.84 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.0, 165.1, 161.7, 158.6, 156.8, 156.7, 137.9, 130.5 (2× CH), 122.6, 115.5 (2× CH), 105.8, 98.3, 92.6, 73.2, 68.7, 29.6, 28.6, 28.0, 27.9, 22.4, 22.4, 14.0, 13.9. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C25H31O6 [M + H]+, 427.2121; found, 427.2111.

    7-(Heptyloxy)-2-(4-(heptyloxy)phenyl)-3,5-dihydroxy-4H-chromen-4-one (3)

    Compound 3 was synthesized by kaempferol (200 mg, 0.699 mmol), potassium carbonate (289.7 mg, 2.1 mmol), and 1-iodoheptane (170.48 μL, 1.05 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 1. The product was obtained as a brownish yellow solid (88.6 mg, 26%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.66 (s, 1H), 8.15–7.91 (m, 2H), 7.16–6.81 (m, 2H), 6.43 (d, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H), 6.34 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 3.99 (dt, J = 19.9, 6.6 Hz, 4H), 1.84–1.66 (m, 4H), 1.39–1.20 (m, 16H), 0.91–0.83 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.1, 165.1, 161.9, 158.4, 156.9, 156.5, 138.0, 130.7, 130.7, 123.0, 115.6, 115.5, 106.0, 98.4, 92.7, 73.2, 68.8, 31.8, 31.8, 30.1, 29.1, 29.1, 29.0, 26.0, 25.90, 22.7, 22.6, 14.2, 14.1. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C29H39O6 [M + H]+, 483.2747; found, 483.2737.

    3,5-Dihydroxy-7-(nonyloxy)-2-(4-(nonyloxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (4)

    Compound 4 was synthesized from kaempferol (100 mg, 0.349 mmol), potassium carbonate (96.57 mg, 0.699 mmol), and 1-iodononane (112 μL, 0.629 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 1. The reaction mixture was stirred at RT for 4 h. Then, the resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 4:1, v/v). The product was obtained as a yellow solid (34.4 mg, 18%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.67 (s, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 6.95 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2H), 6.42 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.34 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 3.99 (dt, J = 16.3, 6.7 Hz, 4H), 1.87–1.61 (m, 6H), 1.48–1.40 (m, 2H), 1.35–1.23 (m, 20H), 0.88 (dt, J = 4.7, 3.5 Hz, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.1, 165.1, 161.9, 158.6, 156.9, 156.7, 138.0, 130.6 (2× CH), 122.8, 115.6 (2× CH), 105.9, 98.4, 92.7, 73.3, 68.8, 31.9 (2× CH2), 30.1, 29.8, 29.6, 29.5, 29.4, 29.3 (2× CH2), 29.0, 26.0, 25.9, 22.7 (2× CH2), 14.2 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): C33H47O6 [M + H]+, 539.3373; found, 539.3356.

    3,5-Dihydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (5)

    Compound 5 was synthesized from kaempferol (200 mg, 0.699 mmol), potassium carbonate (483 mg, 3.49 mmol), and 3,3-dimethylallyl bromide (170 μL, 1.47 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 1. The reaction mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 1.5 h. Then, the resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 4:1, v/v). The product was obtained as a light yellow solid (142.9 mg, 50%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.68 (s, 1H), 8.03 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 2H), 6.98 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2H), 6.45 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 6.36 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 5.63–5.21 (m, 2H), 4.57 (d, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 4.52 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 1.84–1.72 (m, 6H), 1.67–1.54 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.2, 164.9, 161.7, 159.1, 157.5, 156.9, 139.7, 139.4, 137.3, 130.7 (2× CH), 122.6, 119.6, 118.6, 115.8 (2× CH), 105.8, 98.7, 93.0, 69.3, 65.6, 25.9, 25.8, 18.4, 18.0. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C25H27O6 [M + H]+, 423.1808; found, 423.1797.

    3-(3-Bromopropoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-propoxy-2-(4-propoxyphenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (6)

    To a solution of 1 (56.5 mg, 0.153 mmol) in acetone (10 mL), potassium carbonate (105.4 mg, 0.76 mmol) and 1,3-dibromopropane (46.43 μL, 0.46 mmol) were added. The mixture was refluxed for 4 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 7:1, v/v) to give compound 6 as a yellow solid (35.1 mg, 47%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.67 (s, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 2H), 7.01 (d, J = 9.3 Hz, 2H), 6.42 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 6.33 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 3.96 (dt, J = 11.8, 6.8 Hz, 4H), 3.63 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 2.46–2.25 (m, 2H), 1.88–1.61 (m, 4H), 1.04 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H), 0.95 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.0, 165.0, 162.0, 160.7, 156.8, 156.1, 138.1, 130.4 (2× CH), 123.4, 114.4 (2× CH), 106.0, 98.3, 92.6, 74.6, 70.2, 65.5, 32.3, 29.9, 23.4, 22.4, 10.5 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C24H28BrO6 [M + H]+, 491.1069; found, 491.1055.

    3-(3-Bromopropoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-(pentyloxy)-2-(4-(pentyloxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (7)

    Compound 7 was synthesized from 2 (61.2 mg, 0.143 mmol), potassium carbonate (59.5 mg, 0.43 mmol), and 1,3-dibromopropane (43.8 μL, 0.43 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The product was obtained as a yellow solid (40.5 mg, 56%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.67 (s, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.01 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 6.42 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 6.33 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (t, J = 5.8 Hz, 2H), 3.99 (dt, J = 13.4, 6.7 Hz, 4H), 3.63 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 2.43–2.31 (m, 2H), 1.85–1.76 (m, 2H), 1.76–1.67 (m, 2H), 1.45–1.27 (m, 8H), 0.94 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H), 0.87 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.0, 165.0, 162.0, 160.7, 156.8, 156.1, 138.2, 130.4 (2× CH), 123.4, 114.4 (2× CH), 106.0, 98.3, 92.6, 73.1, 68.7, 65.5, 32.3, 29.9, 29.8, 28.7, 28.2, 28.1, 22.5 (2× CH2), 14.1 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H36BrO6 [M + H]+, 547.1695; found, 547.1679.

    3-(3-Bromopropoxy)-7-(heptyloxy)-2-(4-(heptyloxy)phenyl)-5-hydroxy-4H-chromen-4-one (8)

    Compound 8 was synthesized from 3 (88.6 mg, 0.184 mmol), potassium carbonate (63.4 mg, 0.46 mmol), and 1,3-dibromopropane (139.8 μL, 1.38 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The product was obtained as a yellow solid (79.1 mg, 72%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.68 (s, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.01 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 6.42 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.33 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (t, J = 5.8 Hz, 2H), 4.00 (dt, J = 12.1, 6.7 Hz, 4H), 3.63 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 2.37 (p, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 1.85–1.75 (m, 2H), 1.75–1.66 (m, 2H), 1.48–1.24 (m, 16H), 0.91–0.83 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.0, 165.0, 162.0, 160.7, 156.9, 156.1, 138.2, 130.4 (2× CH), 123.4, 114.4 (2× CH), 106.0, 98.3, 92.6, 73.1, 68.7, 65.5, 32.3, 31.9, 31.8, 30.2, 29.9, 29.1 (2× CH2), 29.0, 26.0, 25.9, 22.7 (2× CH2), 14.2 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C32H44BrO6 [M + H]+, 603.2321; found, 603.2307.

    3-(3-Bromopropoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-(nonyloxy)-2-(4-(nonyloxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (9)

    Compound 9 was synthesized from 4 (98 mg, 0.182 mmol), potassium carbonate (62.9 mg, 0.45 mmol), and 1,3-dibromopropane (138.4 μL, 1.36 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The product was obtained as a yellow solid (69.5 mg, 58%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.68 (s, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.01 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 6.42 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.33 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (t, J = 5.8 Hz, 2H), 4.00 (dt, J = 11.6, 6.6 Hz, 4H), 3.63 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 2.37 (p, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 1.84–1.65 (m, 4H), 1.46–1.24 (m, 24H), 0.87 (dt, J = 4.8, 3.4 Hz, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.0, 164.9, 161.9, 160.6, 156.7, 155.9, 138.1, 130.3 (2× CH), 123.3, 114.3 (2× CH), 105.9, 98.2, 92.5, 73.0, 68.6, 65.4, 32.2, 31.9, 31.8, 30.1, 29.7, 29.5 (2× CH2), 29.4, 29.3, 29.2 (2× CH2), 28.9, 25.90 (2× CH2), 22.6 (2× CH2), 14.1 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C36H52BrO6 [M + H]+, 659.2947; found, 659.2933.

    3-(3-Bromopropoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (10)

    Compound 10 was synthesized from 5 (30 mg, 0.071 mmol), potassium carbonate (25.1 mg, 0.18 mmol), and 1,3-dibromopropane (54 μL, 0.53 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 6 h. Then, the resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 6:1, v/v). The product was obtained as a brownish-yellow solid (29.3 mg, 76%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.77–12.67 (m, 1H), 8.22–7.96 (m, 2H), 7.13–6.87 (m, 2H), 6.54–6.40 (m, 1H), 6.38–6.27 (m, 1H), 5.61–5.26 (m, 2H), 4.71–4.43 (m, 4H), 4.19 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 3.78–3.48 (m, 2H), 2.52–2.27 (m, 2H), 1.92–1.72 (m, 6H), 1.68 (s, 3H), 1.62 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 178.9, 164.5, 161.9, 160.5, 156.6, 156.2, 139.4, 139.1, 137.4, 130.3 (2× CH), 123.4, 119.7, 118.6, 114.2 (2× CH), 105.8, 98.2, 92.7, 68.8, 65.4, 65.3, 32.1, 29.7, 25.8, 25.7, 18.2, 18.0. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H32BrO6 [M + H]+, 543.1382; found, 543.1363.

    3-(3-(Diethylamino)propoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-propoxy-2-(4-propoxyphenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (11)

    To a solution of 6 (47.8 mg, 0.097 mmol) in anhydrous DMF (4 mL), diethylamine (1 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred for 24 h at 50 °C. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (ethyl acetate/ethanol/triethylamine, 1/1/0.1, v/v/v) to give compound 11 as a yellow gel (27.1 mg, 58%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.04–7.95 (m, 2H), 7.02–6.93 (m, 2H), 6.49–6.40 (m, 1H), 6.26–6.19 (m, 1H), 4.11–4.03 (m, 2H), 4.00–3.94 (m, 2H), 3.90–3.83 (m, 2H), 2.73–2.67 (m, 2H), 2.62 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 2.02–1.94 (m, 2H), 1.84–1.66 (m, 4H), 1.10–1.02 (m, 9H), 0.94 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3OD): δ 180.1, 166.6, 162.8, 162.6, 158.2, 157.7, 139.1, 131.5, 131.4, 124.0, 115.4 (2× CH), 106.8, 99.3, 93.5, 75.5, 71.4, 67.5, 50.4, 47.9 (2× CH2), 27.1, 24.4, 23.5, 11.4 (2× CH3), 10.9, 10.8. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C28H38NO6 [M + H]+, 484.2699; found, 484.2676.

    3-(3-(Diethylamino)propoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-(pentyloxy)-2-(4-(pentyloxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (12)

    Compound 12 was synthesized from 7 (50 mg, 0.091 mmol) and diethylamine (1 mL) according to the procedure used to prepare 11. The product was obtained as a brownish yellow solid (31.4 mg, 64%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 7.96 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.96 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.41 (s, 1H), 6.19 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 4.06 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 2H), 3.97 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 3.89 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 2.73–2.66 (m, 2H), 2.61 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 2.02–1.92 (m, 2H), 1.80–1.63 (m, 4H), 1.48–1.29 (m, 8H), 1.08 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 6H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H), 0.88 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3OD): δ 180.0, 166.4, 162.8, 162.5, 158.0, 157.5, 139.0, 131.4 (2× CH), 123.9, 115.4 (2× CH), 106.7, 99.2, 93.4, 73.8, 69.8, 67.5, 50.3, 47.9 (2× CH2), 30.9, 29.9, 29.3 (2× CH2), 27.1, 23.6, 23.5, 14.5 (2× CH3), 11.5 (2× CH3). HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C32H46NO6 [M + H]+, 540.3325; found, 540.3301.

    3-(3-(Diethylamino)propoxy)-7-(heptyloxy)-2-(4-(heptyloxy)phenyl)-5-hydroxy-4H-chromen-4-one (13)

    Compound 13 was synthesized from 8 (63.8 mg, 0.106 mmol) and diethylamine (1 mL) according to the procedure used to prepare 11.     3-(3-(Dimethylamino)propoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (28)

    3-(3-(Dipropylamino)propoxy)-5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4H-chromen-4-one (29)

    3-((5-Hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)-N,N,N-trimethylpropan-1-aminium Iodide (38)

    To a solution of 28 (39.8 mg, 0.078 mmol) in methanol (8 mL), iodomethane (1.5 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred overnight at RT. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was diluted with n-butanol and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by HPLC to yield compound 38 as a yellow gel (49.2 mg, 71%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.09 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.08 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.56 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 6.31 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 5.51–5.44 (m, 1H), 5.36–5.28 (m, 1H), 4.62 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 4.53 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 4.22 (t, J = 5.6 Hz, 2H), 3.69–3.55 (m, 2H), 3.22 (s, 9H), 2.42–2.29 (m, 2H), 1.81 (s, 3H), 1.78 (s, 3H), 1.64 (s, 3H), 1.57 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3OD): δ 180.3, 166.4, 162.8, 161.9, 158.2, 158.0, 140.6, 139.8, 138.4, 131.6 (2× CH), 124.8, 120.8, 120.2, 115.4 (2× CH), 106.6, 99.5, 93.8, 69.8 (2× CH2), 66.6 (2× CH2), 53.8, 53.7 (2× CH3), 25.9 (2× CH3), 24.3, 18.3, 18.0. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C31H40INO6 [M – I]+, 522.2850; found, 522.2846.

    N,N-Diethyl-3-((5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)-N-methylpropan-1-aminium (39)

HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C33H44INO6 [M – I]+, 550.3163; found, 550.3156.

    N-Butyl-N-(3-((5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)propyl)-N-methylbutan-1-aminium (40)

    Ethyl 2-((5-Hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetate (41)

    Compound 41 was synthesized from 5 (200 mg, 0.473 mmol), ethyl bromoacetate (105 μL, 0.947 mmol), and potassium carbonate (130.8 mg, 0.947 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 4 h. Then, the resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 4:1, v/v). The product was obtained as a yellow solid (165 mg, 69%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 12.68 (s, 1H), 8.09 (d, J = 9.3 Hz, 2H), 7.00 (d, J = 9.3 Hz, 2H), 6.43 (d, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H), 6.35 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 5.84–5.23 (m, 2H), 4.86–4.42 (m, 6H), 4.36–4.16 (m, 2H), 1.91–1.45 (m, 12H), 1.31 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 179.1, 168.5, 164.8, 162.0, 159.6, 156.8, 156.1, 139.6, 139.3, 137.7, 130.5 (2× CH), 124.4, 119.8, 118.7, 114.5 (2× CH), 106.0, 98.4, 92.8, 69.0, 65.5, 65.3, 61.7, 25.9, 25.8, 18.4, 18.1, 14.3. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C29H33O8 [M + H]+, 509.2175; found, 509.2158.

    Dimethyl 2,2′-((7-((3-Methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromene-3,5-diyl)bis(oxy))diacetate (42)

    Compound 42 was synthesized from 5 (224 mg, 0.53 mmol), ethyl bromoacetate (235.2 μL, 2.12 mmol), and potassium carbonate (293 mg, 2.12 mmol) according to the similar procedure used to prepare 6. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 12 h. Then, the resulting residue was purified by silica gel chromatography (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate, 2:1, v/v). The product was obtained as a yellow gel (228.8 mg, 72%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.11–8.05 (m, 2H), 7.01–6.99 (m, 1H), 6.99–6.97 (m, 1H), 6.56 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.28 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 5.53–5.39 (m, 2H), 4.78 (s, 2H), 4.69 (s, 2H), 4.60–4.53 (m, 4H), 4.33–4.23 (m, 4H), 1.82 (s, 3H), 1.76 (s, 3H), 1.68 (s, 3H), 1.63 (s, 3H), 1.31 (t, J = 5.2 Hz, 3H), 1.28 (t, J = 5.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 174.0, 168.6, 168.4, 162.8, 159.2, 159.1, 158.8, 153.0, 140.1, 139.7, 139.1, 130.2 (2× CH), 124.7, 120.3, 118.5, 114.4 (2× CH), 110.0, 100.0, 94.7, 68.7, 66.8, 65.5, 65.4, 61.6, 61.5, 25.9, 25.8, 18.3, 18.2, 14.3, 14.2. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C33H39O10 [M + H]+, 595.2543; found, 595.2520.

    Methyl (2-((5-Hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetyl)-l-argininate (45)

    To a solution of 41 (60.4 mg, 0.126 mmol) in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (10 mL), an aqueous solution (5 mL) of LiOH (15.1 mg, 0.63 mmol) was added. After stirring for 1.5 h at RT, the reaction mixture was acidified with acetic acid, diluted with n-butanol, and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure to give crude product 43 that was used for the next step reaction without further purification. Subsequently, 43 was dissolved in anhydrous DMF (5 mL), and HATU (95.6 mg, 0.251 mmol), H-Arg-OMe·2HCl (65.6 mg, 0.251 mmol), and DIPEA (83.1 μL, 0.503 mmol) were added. The mixture was stirred at RT for 24 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was diluted with n-butanol and washed twice with water. The organic phase was concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was purified by HPLC to yield compound 45 as a brown foam (81.8 mg, 74%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.09 (d, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 7.12 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 6.53 (s, 1H), 6.28 (s, 1H), 5.52–5.42 (m, 1H), 5.33 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 4.69 (s, 2H), 4.64–4.56 (m, 3H), 4.53 (d, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 3.75 (s, 3H), 3.28–3.15 (m, 2H), 2.06–1.74 (m, 8H), 1.70–1.61 (m, 5H), 1.57 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3OD): δ 180.3, 173.3, 170.8, 166.4, 162.7, 161.1, 158.7, 158.1, 157.7, 140.7, 139.7, 138.5, 131.5 (2× CH), 125.3, 120.8, 120.2, 115.8 (2× CH), 106.6, 99.4, 93.8, 69.8, 68.0, 66.6, 53.0, 52.9, 41.8, 29.5, 26.3, 25.9 (2× CH3), 18.3, 18.1. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C34H43N4O9 [M + H]+, 651.3030; found, 651.3002.

    Methyl (2-((5-Hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetyl)-l-histidinate (46)

    Compound 46 was synthesized from 41 (60.4 mg, 0.126 mmol), HATU (95.6 mg, 0.251 mmol), H-His-OMe·2HCl (60.8 mg, 0.251 mmol), and DIPEA (83.1 μL, 0.503 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C34H38N3O9 [M + H]+, 632.2608; found, 632.2575.

    N-(3-(Dimethylamino)propyl)-2-((5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetamide (47)

    Compound 47 was synthesized from 41 (60 mg, 0.125 mmol), HATU (94.9 mg, 0.25 mmol), N,N-dimethylpropane-1,3-diamine (31.6 μL, 0.25 mmol), and DIPEA (82.6 μL, 0.50 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C32H41N2O7 [M + H]+, 565.2914; found, 565.2916.

    N-(3-(Diethylamino)propyl)-2-((5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetamide (48)

    Compound 48 was synthesized from 41 (60 mg, 0.125 mmol), HATU (197.7 mg, 0.25 mmol), N,N-diethylpropane-1,3-diamine (39.3 μL, 0.25 mmol), and DIPEA (82.6 μL, 0.50 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45.     Methyl (2-((5-Hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetyl)-l-arginyl-l-argininate (50)

    Compound 50 was synthesized from 45 (68.9 mg, 0.108 mmol), HATU (82.3 mg, 0.216 mmol), H-Arg-OMe·2HCl (50.4 mg, 0.216 mmol), and DIPEA (71.6 μL, 0.433 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45.     (S)-N-(3-(Dimethylamino)propyl)-5-guanidino-2-(2-((5-hydroxy-7-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromen-3-yl)oxy)acetamido)pentanamide (51)

    Compound 51 was synthesized from 45 (58.7 mg, 0.092 mmol), HATU (87.6 mg, 0.23 mmol), N,N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine (69.6 μL, 0.553 mmol), and DIPEA (76 μL, 0.46 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45.     Dimethyl 2,2′-((2,2′-((7-((3-Methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromene-3,5-diyl)bis(oxy))bis(acetyl))bis(azanediyl)) (2S,2′S)-bis(5-guanidinopentanoate) (52)

    Compound 52 was synthesized from 42 (189 mg, 0.351 mmol), HATU (533.8 mg, 1.40 mmol), H-Arg-OMe·2HCl (366.6 mg, 1.40 mmol), and DIPEA (464 μL, 2.81 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C43H59N8O12 [M + H]+, 879.4252; found, 879.4223.

    2,2′-((7-((3-Methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromene-3,5-diyl)bis(oxy))bis(N-(3-(dimethylamino)propyl)acetamide) (53)

    Compound 53 was synthesized from 42 (70 mg, 0.130 mmol), HATU (197.7 mg, 0.52 mmol), N,N-dimethylpropane-1,3-diamine (65.4 μL, 0.52 mmol), and DIPEA (171.8 μL, 1.04 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45. The product was obtained as a yellow gel (69.6 mg, 76%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.10 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.11 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 6.72 (s, 1H), 6.45 (s, 1H), 5.53–5.40 (m, 1H), 5.32 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 4.64 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 2H), 4.59 (s, 4H), 4.50 (d, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 3.41 (t, J = 6.7 Hz, 2H), 3.34–3.30 (m, 2H), 2.63–2.54 (m, 2H), 2.40 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 2.34 (s, 6H), 2.26 (s, 6H), 1.92–1.83 (m, 2H), 1.79 (s, 3H), 1.77 (s, 3H), 1.75–1.69 (m, 2H), 1.63 (s, 3H), 1.55 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD3OD): δ 176.2, 171.3, 169.8, 165.4, 160.9, 159.8, 159.2, 156.0, 140.5, 140.4, 140.0, 131.5 (2× CH), 125.4, 121.0, 120.0, 115.8 (2× CH), 109.7, 99.5, 95.9, 69.7, 69.3, 68.1, 66.9, 56.7, 56.6, 43.6 (2× CH3), 43.5 (2× CH3), 37.0 (2× CH2), 26.1, 26.0, 25.9 (2× CH3), 18.3, 18.2.     2,2′-((7-((3-Methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)-2-(4-((3-methylbut-2-en-1-yl)oxy)phenyl)-4-oxo-4H-chromene-3,5-diyl)bis(oxy))bis(N-(3-(diethylamino)propyl)acetamide) (54)

    Compound 54 was synthesized from 42 (70 mg, 0.130 mmol), HATU (197.7 mg, 0.52 mmol), N,N-diethylpropane-1,3-diamine (82.0 μL, 0.52 mmol), and DIPEA (171.8 μL, 1.04 mmol) according to the procedure used to prepare 45. HRMS (ESI+): calcd for C43H63N4O8 [M + H]+, 763.4646; found, 763.4614.

    Antibacterial Assay

    The MICs were measured in accordance with Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines by broth microdilution methods. Bacterial cells were inoculated on Mueller–Hinton agar (MHA) plates at 37 °C for 24 h and adjusted to approximately 1 × 106 CFU/mL. Samples were first dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)/H2O to prepare stock solutions (the final concentration of DMSO ≤2%). These samples were diluted in Mueller–Hinton Broth (MHB) medium to 100 μg/mL as the initial concentration. An aliquot (100 μL) of the bacterial suspension (1 × 106 CFU/mL) was added to the two-fold serial dilutions of samples (100 μL) in each well of 96-well plates. The 96-well plates were then incubated for 24 h at 37 °C. The lowest sample concentration to prevent the visible growth of bacteria was recorded as an MIC value. The MIC values were determined by measuring the OD600 and visible observations. All experiments were carried out at least twice and with biological replicates.

    Hemolytic Activity

    The hemolysis experiment was performed as described in previous reports.(21,34) First, rabbit RBCs were centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 3 min and washed twice with PBS. Subsequently, the RBCs were suspended in PBS to prepare an 8% v/v suspension. The samples were first dissolved in DMSO or PBS and then diluted in PBS to prepare two-fold serial dilutions. The RBC suspension (100 μL) was incubated with two-fold serial dilutions of samples (100 μL) at 37 °C for 1 h. The final concentration of DMSO and RBCs in the mixture was controlled at 0.5 and 4%, respectively. Then, the mixture was centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 5 min, and the supernatant (100 μL) was transferred into a 96-well plate. The absorbance at 576 nm was determined using a BioTek multidetector microplate reader. 2% Triton X-100 solution was used as a positive control; PBS or 0.5% DMSO was used as a negative control. The hemolytic activity was calculated by the following equation: % hemolysis = [(Abssample – Absnegative control)/(Abspositive control – Absnegative control)] × 100. All experiments were performed at least twice and with biological replicates.

    Time-Kill Study

    Bacterial cells (S. aureus ATCC29213) were inoculated on MHA plates at 37 °C for 24 h and adjusted to approximately 1 × 106 CFU/mL. The bacterial suspension (1 mL) was treated with various concentrations (the final concentration = 4× and 8× MIC) of compound 45 or 52 (1 mL) and were incubated at 37 °C. At 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, and 24 h, the culture samples (100 μL) were separately removed and 10-fold serially diluted in PBS. Then, each dilution was plated onto the MHA plate and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. Finally, the number of bacterial colony growth on plates was counted. All experiments were performed at least twice and with biological replicates.

    Resistance Development Study

    The initial MICs of the compounds 45 and 52 against S. aureus ATCC29213 were obtained from the above method. Bacterial cells in a 96-well plate at a concentration of 0.5× MIC were used to prepare the bacterial suspension (∼106 CFU/mL) for the next MIC measurement. After incubation with samples at 37 °C for 24 h, the new MICs were determined. The experiment lasted for 19 days.

    SYTOX Green Assay

    Bacteria were first incubated overnight on MHA plates. These bacterial cells were then washed twice with PBS buffer (10 mM, pH = 7.2) and resuspended in PBS to adjust the bacterial cell concentration with an optical density at 600 nm of 0.2. The bacterial suspension was incubated in the dark with 0.3 μM SYTOX Green. The change in fluorescence intensity of the SYTOX Green dye was monitored using a microplate reader (excitation wavelength: 504 nm, emission wavelength: 523 nm). After the fluorescence signal was stable, test samples (1×, 2×, 4× and 8× MIC) dissolved in PBS/DMSO (final concentration of DMSO = 0.5%) were immediately added to the SYTOX Green-treated bacterial suspension. The change in fluorescence intensity that lasted for about 60 min was recorded. The blank control group consisted of 0.5% DMSO. All experiments were performed at least twice and with biological replicates.

    Scanning Electron Microscopy

    S. aureus ATCC29213 cells were grown to the exponential phase, centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5 min, washed twice with PBS (pH = 7.2), and resuspended in PBS to yield 5 × 107 CFU/mL. Compound 45 or 52 (8× MIC) was incubated with S. aureus ATCC29213 cells for 2 h at 37 °C, centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5 min, and then washed twice with PBS. The bacterial cells treated with PBS were used as a negative control. The cell pellets were treated with 2.5% glutaraldehyde overnight at 4 °C. The cells were washed with fresh PBS and dehydrated with different gradients of ethanol (30, 50, 70, 90, and 95%). The cells were then treated three times with acetone and twice with tert-butanol and dried in vacuum. The samples were coated with gold and analyzed using a Thermo Scientific Apreo.

    LIVE/DEAD Fluorescence Staining Assay

    Bacterial membrane integrity was determined by using LIVE/DEAD BacLight bacterial viability kits L7007 (ThermoFisher, USA). S. aureus ATCC29213 in the logarithmic growth phase was centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5 min, washed twice with PBS (10 mM, pH = 7.2), and resuspended in PBS to adjust the cell concentration to about 1 × 108 CFU/mL (OD600 of 0.3–0.4). Then, compounds 45 and 52 (final concentration of 8× MIC) were mixed with the bacterial suspension and incubated at 37 °C for 2 h (150 rpm). After incubation, each sample was incubated with Syto 9 (5 μM) and PI stain (30 μM) in the dark for 15 min. Smears were prepared, and the cells were observed under a laser confocal microscope (ZEISS LSM 880). The treatment with sterile PBS was used as a negative control. The experiments were repeated twice.

    Cytotoxicity Assay

    MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells or mouse corneal epithelial cells were cultured in 96-well plates, the cells were treated with two-fold serial dilutions of samples at 37 °C for 24 h with 5% CO2, and then 10 μL of CCK-8 reagent was added to each well at 37 °C for 1 h with 5% CO2. Absorbance was measured using a BioTek multidetector microplate reader at 450 nm. The percent viability of cells was calculated using the ratio of OD450 for compound-treated cells to OD450 for untreated cells. All experiments were performed at least three times with biological replicates.

    In Vivo Efficacy

    Animal experiments were approved by the Laboratory Animal Center of South China Agricultural University and carried out in accordance with the policy of the Ministry of Health. Female C57BL6 mice (6–8 weeks, ∼20 g) were used. Bacterial cells (S. aureus ATCC 29213) were inoculated on MHA plates at 37 °C for 24 h and adjusted to approximately 5 × 107 CFU/mL for mice corneal infection.
    The mice were immunosuppressed by intraperitoneal injection of cyclophosphamide (100 mg/kg) three times in 5 days before infection. Tribromoethanol (500 mg) was dissolved in tert-amyl alcohol (310 μL) to prepare 100% avertin and then diluted with sterile saline to prepare the anesthetics (2.5% avertin). The mice were anesthetized by intraperitoneal injection of 2.5% avertin (500 mg/kg). Mice corneal scratches of the left eye were created by sterile needles. Then, 15 μL of bacterial inoculum was dropped onto the injured cornea. One day after infection, these mice were randomly divided into three groups (five mice/group). Then, the respective compounds (5% vancomycin, 0.5% compound 52, or 5% dextrose solution) were applied topically four times each day for 3 days. The mice were finally sacrificed. The infected corneas were collected and plated onto MHA plates for counting the numbers of viable bacteria. Statistical significance was calculated using the SPSS 22.0 software. P values were calculated using the independent t-test, and P ≤ 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

    Supporting Information

    1. 1
      Theuretzbacher, U.; Gottwalt, S.; Beyer, P.; Butler, M.; Czaplewski, L.; Lienhardt, C.; Moja, L.; Paul, M.; Paulin, S.; Rex, J. H.; Silver, L. L.; Spigelman, M.; Thwaites, G. E.; Paccaud, J.-P.; Harbarth, S. Analysis of the clinical antibacterial and antituberculosis pipeline. Lancet Infect. Dis. 2019, 19, e40– e50,  DOI: 10.1016/s1473-3099(18)30513-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Analysis of the clinical antibacterial and antituberculosis pipeline
      Theuretzbacher, Ursula; Gottwalt, Simon; Beyer, Peter; Butler, Mark; Czaplewski, Lloyd; Lienhardt, Christian; Moja, Lorenzo; Paul, Mical; Paulin, Sarah; Rex, John H.; Silver, Lynn L.; Spigelman, Melvin; Thwaites, Guy E.; Paccaud, Jean-Pierre; Harbarth, Stephan
      Lancet Infectious Diseases (2019), 19 (2), e40-e50CODEN: LIDABP; ISSN:1473-3099. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      This anal. of the global clin. antibacterial pipeline was done in support of the Global Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance. The study analyzed to what extent antibacterial and antimycobacterial drugs for systemic human use as well as oral non-systemic antibacterial drugs for Clostridium difficile infections were active against pathogens included in the WHO priority pathogen list and their innovativeness measured by their absence of cross-resistance (new class, target, mode of action). As of July 1, 2018, 30 new chem. entity (NCE) antibacterial drugs, ten biologics, ten NCEs against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and four NCEs against C difficile were identified. Of the 30 NCEs, 11 are expected to have some activity against at least one crit. priority pathogen expressing carbapenem resistance. The clin. pipeline is dominated by derivs. of established classes and most development candidates display limited innovation. New antibacterial drugs without pre-existing cross-resistance are under-represented and are urgently needed, esp. for geog. regions with high resistance rates among Gram-neg. bacteria and M tuberculosis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvFejtbvP&md5=38cf1c2a98bc2e353a6fa0fc01acce8d
    2. 2
      Roope, L. S. J.; Smith, R. D.; Pouwels, K. B.; Buchanan, J.; Abel, L.; Eibich, P.; Butler, C. C.; Tan, P. S.; Walker, A. S.; Robotham, J. V.; Wordsworth, S. The challenge of antimicrobial resistance: What economics can contribute. Science 2019, 364, eaau4679  DOI: 10.1126/science.aau4679
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

    3. 3
      Rossolini, G. M.; Arena, F.; Pecile, P.; Pollini, S. Update on the antibiotic resistance crisis. Curr. Opin. Pharmacol. 2014, 18, 56– 60,  DOI: 10.1016/j.coph.2014.09.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Update on the antibiotic resistance crisis
      Rossolini, Gian Maria; Arena, Fabio; Pecile, Patrizia; Pollini, Simona
      Current Opinion in Pharmacology (2014), 18 (), 56-60CODEN: COPUBK; ISSN:1471-4892. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Antibiotics tend to lose their efficacy over time due to the emergence and dissemination of resistance among bacterial pathogens. Strains with resistance to multiple antibiotic classes have emerged among major Gram-pos. and Gram-neg. species including Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus spp., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter spp. Enterobacteriaceae, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. With some Gram-negatives, resistance may involve most or even all the available antimicrobial options, resulting in extremely drug-resistant or totally drug-resistant phenotypes. This so-called 'antibiotic resistance crisis' has been compounded by the lagging in antibiotic discovery and development programs occurred in recent years, and is jeopardizing the essential role played by antibiotics in current medical practices.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFyitLfE&md5=06565fe5cf882954e7f2704b77b5a61d

      Christoffersen, R. E. Antibiotics--an investment worth making?. Nat. Biotechnol. 2006, 24, 1512– 1514,  DOI: 10.1038/nbt1206-1512
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Antibiotics-an investment worth making?

      Nature Biotechnology (2006), 24 (12), 1512-1514CODEN: NABIF9; ISSN:1087-0156. (Nature Publishing Group)

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht12gtb3I&md5=85f28c375852fb4fb5df8b9beb6e19ef
    5. 5
      Lee, A. S.; de Lencastre, H.; Garau, J.; Kluytmans, J.; Malhotra-Kumar, S.; Peschel, A.; Harbarth, S. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Nat. Rev. Dis. Primers 2018, 4, 18033,  DOI: 10.1038/nrdp.2018.33
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
      Lee Andie S; Lee Andie S; de Lencastre Herminia; de Lencastre Herminia; Garau Javier; Kluytmans Jan; Kluytmans Jan; Malhotra-Kumar Surbhi; Peschel Andreas; Peschel Andreas; Harbarth Stephan
      Nature reviews. Disease primers (2018), 4 (), 18033 ISSN:.
      Since the 1960s, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) has emerged, disseminated globally and become a leading cause of bacterial infections in both health-care and community settings. However, there is marked geographical variation in MRSA burden owing to several factors, including differences in local infection control practices and pathogen-specific characteristics of the circulating clones. Different MRSA clones have resulted from the independent acquisition of staphylococcal cassette chromosome mec (SCCmec), which contains genes encoding proteins that render the bacterium resistant to most β-lactam antibiotics (such as methicillin), by several S. aureus clones. The success of MRSA is a consequence of the extensive arsenal of virulence factors produced by S. aureus combined with β-lactam resistance and, for most clones, resistance to other antibiotic classes. Clinical manifestations of MRSA range from asymptomatic colonization of the nasal mucosa to mild skin and soft tissue infections to fulminant invasive disease with high mortality. Although treatment options for MRSA are limited, several new antimicrobials are under development. An understanding of colonization dynamics, routes of transmission, risk factors for progression to infection and conditions that promote the emergence of resistance will enable optimization of strategies to effectively control MRSA. Vaccine candidates are also under development and could become an effective prevention measure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1MbhvF2rtQ%253D%253D&md5=876a11b74542a5f7ae71aee2c7fcfe65
    6. 6
      Hanberger, H.; Walther, S.; Leone, M.; Barie, P. S.; Rello, J.; Lipman, J.; Marshall, J. C.; Anzueto, A.; Sakr, Y.; Pickkers, P.; Felleiter, P.; Engoren, M.; Vincent, J.-L.; Investigators, E. I. G. o. Increased mortality associated with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection in the intensive care unit: results from the EPIC II study. Int. J. Antimicrob. Agents 2011, 38, 331– 335,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijantimicag.2011.05.013
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Increased mortality associated with meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection in the Intensive Care Unit: results from the EPIC II study
      Hanberger, Hakan; Walther, Sten; Leone, Marc; Barie, Philip S.; Rello, Jordi; Lipman, Jeffrey; Marshall, John C.; Anzueto, Antonio; Sakr, Yasser; Pickkers, Peter; Felleiter, Peter; Engoren, Milo; Vincent, Jean-Louis
      International Journal of Antimicrobial Agents (2011), 38 (4), 331-335CODEN: IAAGEA; ISSN:0924-8579. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Controversy continues regarding whether the presence of meticillin resistance increases mortality risk in Staphylococcus aureus infections. In this study, we assessed the role of meticillin resistance in survival of patients with S. aureus infection included in the EPIC II point-prevalence study of infection in critically ill patients performed on 8 May 2007. Demog., physiol., bacteriol. and therapeutic data were collected for 13 796 adult patients in 1265 participating Intensive Care Units (ICUs) from 75 countries on the study day. ICU and hospital outcomes were recorded. Characteristics of patients with meticillin-sensitive S. aureus (MSSA) and meticillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infections were compared. Co-morbidities, age, Simplified Acute Physiol. Score (SAPS) II, site of infection, geog. region and MRSA/MSSA were entered into a multivariate model, and adjusted odds ratios (ORs) [95% confidence interval (CI)] for ICU and hospital mortality rates were calcd. On the study day, 7087 (51%) of the 13 796 patients were classified as infected. There were 494 patients with MRSA infections and 505 patients with MSSA infections. There were no significant differences between the two groups in use of mech. ventilation or haemofiltration/haemodialysis. Cancer and chronic renal failure were more prevalent in MRSA than in MSSA patients. ICU mortality rates were 29.1% and 20.5%, resp. (P < 0.01) and corresponding hospital mortality rates were 36.4% and 27.0% (P < 0.01). Multivariate anal. of hospital mortality for MRSA infection showed an adjusted OR of 1.46 (95% CI 1.03-2.06) (P = 0.03). In ICU patients, MRSA infection is therefore independently assocd. with an almost 50% higher likelihood of hospital death compared with MSSA infection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFSjtLfI&md5=ebcf9c192d594519a4f131b50a4c3c22

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      World Health Organization publishes list that it hopes will focus development of antibiotics.
